text: There was a man in the land of Uz, whose name was Job; and that man was blameless and upright, and one who feared God and shunned evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: And seven sons and three daughters were born to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, his possessions were seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen, five hundred female donkeys, and a very large household, so that this man was the greatest of all the people of the East.
speaker: Narrator

text: And his sons would go and feast in their houses, each on his appointed day, and would send and invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So it was, when the days of feasting had run their course, that Job would send and sanctify them, and he would rise early in the morning and offer burnt offerings according to the number of them all. For Job said, “It may be that my sons have sinned and cursed God in their hearts.” Thus Job did regularly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan also came among them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the Lord said to Satan, “From where do you come?”
So Satan answered the Lord and said, “From going to and fro on the earth, and from walking back and forth on it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Satan, “Have you considered My servant Job, that there is none like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man, one who fears God and shuns evil?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Satan answered the Lord and said, “Does Job fear God for nothing?
speaker: Narrator

text: Have You not made a hedge around him, around his household, and around all that he has on every side? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his possessions have increased in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, stretch out Your hand and touch all that he has, and he will surely curse You to Your face!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the Lord said to Satan, “Behold, all that he has is in your power; only do not lay a hand on his person.”
So Satan went out from the presence of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a day when his sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s house;
speaker: Narrator

text: and a messenger came to Job and said, “The oxen were plowing and the donkeys feeding beside them,
speaker: Narrator

text: when the Sabeans raided them and took them away—indeed they have killed the servants with the edge of the sword; and I alone have escaped to tell you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking, another also came and said, “The fire of God fell from heaven and burned up the sheep and the servants, and consumed them; and I alone have escaped to tell you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking, another also came and said, “The Chaldeans formed three bands, raided the camels and took them away, yes, and killed the servants with the edge of the sword; and I alone have escaped to tell you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking, another also came and said, “Your sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s house,
speaker: Narrator

text: and suddenly a great wind came from across the wilderness and struck the four corners of the house, and it fell on the young people, and they are dead; and I alone have escaped to tell you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job arose, tore his robe, and shaved his head; and he fell to the ground and worshiped.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And he said:
“Naked I came from my mother’s womb,
And naked shall I return there.
The Lord gave, and the Lord has taken away;
Blessed be the name of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In all this Job did not sin nor charge God with wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan came also among them to present himself before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the Lord said to Satan, “From where do you come?”
Satan answered the Lord and said, “From going to and fro on the earth, and from walking back and forth on it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Satan, “Have you considered My servant Job, that there is none like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man, one who fears God and shuns evil? And still he holds fast to his integrity, although you incited Me against him, to destroy him without cause.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Satan answered the Lord and said, “Skin for skin! Yes, all that a man has he will give for his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: But stretch out Your hand now, and touch his bone and his flesh, and he will surely curse You to Your face!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to Satan, “Behold, he is in your hand, but spare his life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Satan went out from the presence of the Lord, and struck Job with painful boils from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he took for himself a potsherd with which to scrape himself while he sat in the midst of the ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his wife said to him, “Do you still hold fast to your integrity? Curse God and die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said to her, “You speak as one of the foolish women speaks. Shall we indeed accept good from God, and shall we not accept adversity?” In all this Job did not sin with his lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Job’s three friends heard of all this adversity that had come upon him, each one came from his own place—Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite. For they had made an appointment together to come and mourn with him, and to comfort him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they raised their eyes from afar, and did not recognize him, they lifted their voices and wept; and each one tore his robe and sprinkled dust on his head toward heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they sat down with him on the ground seven days and seven nights, and no one spoke a word to him, for they saw that his grief was very great.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job spoke, and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“May the day perish on which I was born,
And the night in which it was said,
‘A male child is conceived.’
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Oh, may that night be barren!
May no joyful shout come into it!
speaker: Narrator

text:
May those curse it who curse the day,
Those who are ready to arouse Leviathan.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Because it did not shut up the doors of my mother’s womb,
Nor hide sorrow from my eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why did I not die at birth?
Why did I not perish when I came from the womb?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why did the knees receive me?
Or why the breasts, that I should nurse?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
With kings and counselors of the earth,
Who built ruins for themselves,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or with princes who had gold,
Who filled their houses with silver;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or why was I not hidden like a stillborn child,
Like infants who never saw light?
speaker: Narrator

text:
There the wicked cease from troubling,
And there the weary are at rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There the prisoners rest together;
They do not hear the voice of the oppressor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The small and great are there,
And the servant is free from his master.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why is light given to him who is in misery,
And life to the bitter of soul,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who long for death, but it does not come,
And search for it more than hidden treasures;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who rejoice exceedingly,
And are glad when they can find the grave?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why is light given to a man whose way is hidden,
And whom God has hedged in?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For my sighing comes before I eat,
And my groanings pour out like water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the thing I greatly feared has come upon me,
And what I dreaded has happened to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am not at ease, nor am I quiet;
I have no rest, for trouble comes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If one attempts a word with you, will you become weary?
But who can withhold himself from speaking?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely you have instructed many,
And you have strengthened weak hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your words have upheld him who was stumbling,
And you have strengthened the feeble knees;
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now it comes upon you, and you are weary;
It touches you, and you are troubled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is not your reverence your confidence?
And the integrity of your ways your hope?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Remember now, who ever perished being innocent?
Or where were the upright ever cut off?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even as I have seen,
Those who plow iniquity
And sow trouble reap the same.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the blast of God they perish,
And by the breath of His anger they are consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The roaring of the lion,
The voice of the fierce lion,
And the teeth of the young lions are broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The old lion perishes for lack of prey,
And the cubs of the lioness are scattered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now a word was secretly brought to me,
And my ear received a whisper of it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In disquieting thoughts from the visions of the night,
When deep sleep falls on men,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fear came upon me, and trembling,
Which made all my bones shake.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then a spirit passed before my face;
The hair on my body stood up.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
‘Can a mortal be more righteous than God?
Can a man be more pure than his Maker?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If He puts no trust in His servants,
If He charges His angels with error,
speaker: Narrator

text:
How much more those who dwell in houses of clay,
Whose foundation is in the dust,
Who are crushed before a moth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are broken in pieces from morning till evening;
They perish forever, with no one regarding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does not their own excellence go away?
They die, even without wisdom.’
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For wrath kills a foolish man,
And envy slays a simple one.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have seen the foolish taking root,
But suddenly I cursed his dwelling place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His sons are far from safety,
They are crushed in the gate,
And there is no deliverer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because the hungry eat up his harvest,
Taking it even from the thorns,
And a snare snatches their substance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For affliction does not come from the dust,
Nor does trouble spring from the ground;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet man is born to trouble,
As the sparks fly upward.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But as for me, I would seek God,
And to God I would commit my cause—
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who does great things, and unsearchable,
Marvelous things without number.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He gives rain on the earth,
And sends waters on the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sets on high those who are lowly,
And those who mourn are lifted to safety.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He frustrates the devices of the crafty,
So that their hands cannot carry out their plans.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He catches the wise in their own craftiness,
And the counsel of the cunning comes quickly upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They meet with darkness in the daytime,
And grope at noontime as in the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But He saves the needy from the sword,
From the mouth of the mighty,
And from their hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the poor have hope,
And injustice shuts her mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, happy is the man whom God corrects;
Therefore do not despise the chastening of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He bruises, but He binds up;
He wounds, but His hands make whole.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall deliver you in six troubles,
Yes, in seven no evil shall touch you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In famine He shall redeem you from death,
And in war from the power of the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You shall be hidden from the scourge of the tongue,
And you shall not be afraid of destruction when it comes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You shall laugh at destruction and famine,
And you shall not be afraid of the beasts of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you shall have a covenant with the stones of the field,
And the beasts of the field shall be at peace with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You shall know that your tent is in peace;
You shall visit your dwelling and find nothing amiss.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You shall also know that your descendants shall be many,
And your offspring like the grass of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You shall come to the grave at a full age,
As a sheaf of grain ripens in its season.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Then Job answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Oh, that my grief were fully weighed,
And my calamity laid with it on the scales!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For then it would be heavier than the sand of the sea—
Therefore my words have been rash.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Does the wild donkey bray when it has grass,
Or does the ox low over its fodder?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can flavorless food be eaten without salt?
Or is there any taste in the white of an egg?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My soul refuses to touch them;
They are as loathsome food to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Oh, that I might have my request,
That God would grant me the thing that I long for!
speaker: Narrator

text:
That it would please God to crush me,
That He would loose His hand and cut me off!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“What strength do I have, that I should hope?
And what is my end, that I should prolong my life?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is my strength the strength of stones?
Or is my flesh bronze?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is my help not within me?
And is success driven from me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“To him who is afflicted, kindness should be shown by his friend,
Even though he forsakes the fear of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My brothers have dealt deceitfully like a brook,
Like the streams of the brooks that pass away,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which are dark because of the ice,
And into which the snow vanishes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When it is warm, they cease to flow;
When it is hot, they vanish from their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The paths of their way turn aside,
They go nowhere and perish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The caravans of Tema look,
The travelers of Sheba hope for them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are disappointed because they were confident;
They come there and are confused.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For now you are nothing,
You see terror and are afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did I ever say, ‘Bring something to me’?
Or, ‘Offer a bribe for me from your wealth’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or, ‘Deliver me from the enemy’s hand’?
Or, ‘Redeem me from the hand of oppressors’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Teach me, and I will hold my tongue;
Cause me to understand wherein I have erred.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How forceful are right words!
But what does your arguing prove?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you intend to rebuke my words,
And the speeches of a desperate one, which are as wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, you overwhelm the fatherless,
And you undermine your friend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now therefore, be pleased to look at me;
For I would never lie to your face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yield now, let there be no injustice!
Yes, concede, my righteousness still stands!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is there injustice on my tongue?
Cannot my taste discern the unsavory?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Is there not a time of hard service for man on earth?
Are not his days also like the days of a hired man?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a servant who earnestly desires the shade,
And like a hired man who eagerly looks for his wages,
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I have been allotted months of futility,
And wearisome nights have been appointed to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I lie down, I say, ‘When shall I arise,
And the night be ended?’
For I have had my fill of tossing till dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My flesh is caked with worms and dust,
My skin is cracked and breaks out afresh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle,
And are spent without hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, remember that my life is a breath!
My eye will never again see good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eye of him who sees me will see me no more;
While your eyes are upon me, I shall no longer be.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As the cloud disappears and vanishes away,
So he who goes down to the grave does not come up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall never return to his house,
Nor shall his place know him anymore.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Am I a sea, or a sea serpent,
That You set a guard over me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I say, ‘My bed will comfort me,
My couch will ease my complaint,’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then You scare me with dreams
And terrify me with visions,
speaker: Narrator

text:
So that my soul chooses strangling
And death rather than my body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I loathe my life;
I would not live forever.
Let me alone,
For my days are but a breath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What is man, that You should exalt him,
That You should set Your heart on him,
speaker: Narrator

text:
That You should visit him every morning,
And test him every moment?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How long?
Will You not look away from me,
And let me alone till I swallow my saliva?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have I sinned?
What have I done to You, O watcher of men?
Why have You set me as Your target,
So that I am a burden to myself?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why then do You not pardon my transgression,
And take away my iniquity?
For now I will lie down in the dust,
And You will seek me diligently,
But I will no longer be.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Bildad the Shuhite answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long will you speak these things,
And the words of your mouth be like a strong wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does God subvert judgment?
Or does the Almighty pervert justice?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If your sons have sinned against Him,
He has cast them away for their transgression.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you would earnestly seek God
And make your supplication to the Almighty,
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you were pure and upright,
Surely now He would awake for you,
And prosper your rightful dwelling place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though your beginning was small,
Yet your latter end would increase abundantly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For inquire, please, of the former age,
And consider the things discovered by their fathers;
speaker: Narrator

text:
For we were born yesterday, and know nothing,
Because our days on earth are a shadow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will they not teach you and tell you,
And utter words from their heart?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can the papyrus grow up without a marsh?
Can the reeds flourish without water?
speaker: Narrator

text:
While it is yet green and not cut down,
It withers before any other plant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So are the paths of all who forget God;
And the hope of the hypocrite shall perish,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whose confidence shall be cut off,
And whose trust is a spider’s web.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He leans on his house, but it does not stand.
He holds it fast, but it does not endure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He grows green in the sun,
And his branches spread out in his garden.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His roots wrap around the rock heap,
And look for a place in the stones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If he is destroyed from his place,
Then it will deny him, saying, ‘I have not seen you.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, this is the joy of His way,
And out of the earth others will grow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, God will not cast away the blameless,
Nor will He uphold the evildoers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will yet fill your mouth with laughing,
And your lips with rejoicing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who hate you will be clothed with shame,
And the dwelling place of the wicked will come to nothing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Truly I know it is so,
But how can a man be righteous before God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If one wished to contend with Him,
He could not answer Him one time out of a thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God is wise in heart and mighty in strength.
Who has hardened himself against Him and prospered?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He removes the mountains, and they do not know
When He overturns them in His anger;
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shakes the earth out of its place,
And its pillars tremble;
speaker: Narrator

text:
He commands the sun, and it does not rise;
He seals off the stars;
speaker: Narrator

text:
He alone spreads out the heavens,
And treads on the waves of the sea;
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made the Bear, Orion, and the Pleiades,
And the chambers of the south;
speaker: Narrator

text:
He does great things past finding out,
Yes, wonders without number.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If He goes by me, I do not see Him;
If He moves past, I do not perceive Him;
speaker: Narrator

text:
If He takes away, who can hinder Him?
Who can say to Him, ‘What are You doing?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
God will not withdraw His anger,
The allies of the proud lie prostrate beneath Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How then can I answer Him,
And choose my words to reason with Him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For though I were righteous, I could not answer Him;
I would beg mercy of my Judge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I called and He answered me,
I would not believe that He was listening to my voice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He crushes me with a tempest,
And multiplies my wounds without cause.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will not allow me to catch my breath,
But fills me with bitterness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If it is a matter of strength, indeed He is strong;
And if of justice, who will appoint my day in court?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though I were righteous, my own mouth would condemn me;
Though I were blameless, it would prove me perverse.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I am blameless, yet I do not know myself;
I despise my life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is all one thing;
Therefore I say, ‘He destroys the blameless and the wicked.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
If the scourge slays suddenly,
He laughs at the plight of the innocent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth is given into the hand of the wicked.
He covers the faces of its judges.
If it is not He, who else could it be?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now my days are swifter than a runner;
They flee away, they see no good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They pass by like swift ships,
Like an eagle swooping on its prey.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I say, ‘I will forget my complaint,
I will put off my sad face and wear a smile,’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am afraid of all my sufferings;
I know that You will not hold me innocent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I am condemned,
Why then do I labor in vain?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I wash myself with snow water,
And cleanse my hands with soap,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet You will plunge me into the pit,
And my own clothes will abhor me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For He is not a man, as I am,
That I may answer Him,
And that we should go to court together.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nor is there any mediator between us,
Who may lay his hand on us both.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let Him take His rod away from me,
And do not let dread of Him terrify me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I would speak and not fear Him,
But it is not so with me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will say to God, ‘Do not condemn me;
Show me why You contend with me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does it seem good to You that You should oppress,
That You should despise the work of Your hands,
And smile on the counsel of the wicked?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do You have eyes of flesh?
Or do You see as man sees?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are Your days like the days of a mortal man?
Are Your years like the days of a mighty man,
speaker: Narrator

text:
That You should seek for my iniquity
And search out my sin,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Although You know that I am not wicked,
And there is no one who can deliver from Your hand?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Remember, I pray, that You have made me like clay.
And will You turn me into dust again?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did You not pour me out like milk,
And curdle me like cheese,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Clothe me with skin and flesh,
And knit me together with bones and sinews?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have granted me life and favor,
And Your care has preserved my spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘And these things You have hidden in Your heart;
I know that this was with You:
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I sin, then You mark me,
And will not acquit me of my iniquity.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
If my head is exalted,
You hunt me like a fierce lion,
And again You show Yourself awesome against me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
‘Why then have You brought me out of the womb?
Oh, that I had perished and no eye had seen me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would have been as though I had not been.
I would have been carried from the womb to the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are not my days few?
Cease! Leave me alone, that I may take a little comfort,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before I go to the place from which I shall not return,
To the land of darkness and the shadow of death,
speaker: Narrator

text:
A land as dark as darkness itself,
As the shadow of death, without any order,
Where even the light is like darkness.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Zophar the Naamathite answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Should not the multitude of words be answered?
And should a man full of talk be vindicated?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should your empty talk make men hold their peace?
And when you mock, should no one rebuke you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you have said,
‘My doctrine is pure,
And I am clean in your eyes.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But oh, that God would speak,
And open His lips against you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
That He would show you the secrets of wisdom!
For they would double your prudence.
Know therefore that God exacts from you
Less than your iniquity deserves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you search out the deep things of God?
Can you find out the limits of the Almighty?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are higher than heaven—what can you do?
Deeper than Sheol—what can you know?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their measure is longer than the earth
And broader than the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If He passes by, imprisons, and gathers to judgment,
Then who can hinder Him?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For an empty-headed man will be wise,
When a wild donkey’s colt is born a man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If you would prepare your heart,
And stretch out your hands toward Him;
speaker: Narrator

text:
If iniquity were in your hand, and you put it far away,
And would not let wickedness dwell in your tents;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then surely you could lift up your face without spot;
Yes, you could be steadfast, and not fear;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because you would forget your misery,
And remember it as waters that have passed away,
speaker: Narrator

text:
And your life would be brighter than noonday.
Though you were dark, you would be like the morning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And you would be secure, because there is hope;
Yes, you would dig around you, and take your rest in safety.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You would also lie down, and no one would make you afraid;
Yes, many would court your favor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the eyes of the wicked will fail,
And they shall not escape,
And their hope—loss of life!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“No doubt you are the people,
And wisdom will die with you!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“I am one mocked by his friends,
Who called on God, and He answered him,
The just and blameless who is ridiculed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A lamp is despised in the thought of one who is at ease;
It is made ready for those whose feet slip.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The tents of robbers prosper,
And those who provoke God are secure—
In what God provides by His hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But now ask the beasts, and they will teach you;
And the birds of the air, and they will tell you;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or speak to the earth, and it will teach you;
And the fish of the sea will explain to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who among all these does not know
That the hand of the Lord has done this,
speaker: Narrator

text:
In whose hand is the life of every living thing,
And the breath of all mankind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does not the ear test words
And the mouth taste its food?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom is with aged men,
And with length of days, understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“With Him are wisdom and strength,
He has counsel and understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If He breaks a thing down, it cannot be rebuilt;
If He imprisons a man, there can be no release.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If He withholds the waters, they dry up;
If He sends them out, they overwhelm the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With Him are strength and prudence.
The deceived and the deceiver are His.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He leads counselors away plundered,
And makes fools of the judges.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He loosens the bonds of kings,
And binds their waist with a belt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He leads princes away plundered,
And overthrows the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He deprives the trusted ones of speech,
And takes away the discernment of the elders.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He pours contempt on princes,
And disarms the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He uncovers deep things out of darkness,
And brings the shadow of death to light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He makes nations great, and destroys them;
He enlarges nations, and guides them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He takes away the understanding of the chiefs of the people of the earth,
And makes them wander in a pathless wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They grope in the dark without light,
And He makes them stagger like a drunken man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, my eye has seen all this,
My ear has heard and understood it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What you know, I also know;
I am not inferior to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I would speak to the Almighty,
And I desire to reason with God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you forgers of lies,
You are all worthless physicians.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, that you would be silent,
And it would be your wisdom!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now hear my reasoning,
And heed the pleadings of my lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you speak wickedly for God,
And talk deceitfully for Him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you show partiality for Him?
Will you contend for God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will it be well when He searches you out?
Or can you mock Him as one mocks a man?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will surely rebuke you
If you secretly show partiality.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will not His excellence make you afraid,
And the dread of Him fall upon you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your platitudes are proverbs of ashes,
Your defenses are defenses of clay.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Hold your peace with me, and let me speak,
Then let come on me what may!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do I take my flesh in my teeth,
And put my life in my hands?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though He slay me, yet will I trust Him.
Even so, I will defend my own ways before Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He also shall be my salvation,
For a hypocrite could not come before Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen carefully to my speech,
And to my declaration with your ears.
speaker: Narrator

text:
See now, I have prepared my case,
I know that I shall be vindicated.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is he who will contend with me?
If now I hold my tongue, I perish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Only two things do not do to me,
Then I will not hide myself from You:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Withdraw Your hand far from me,
And let not the dread of You make me afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then call, and I will answer;
Or let me speak, then You respond to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How many are my iniquities and sins?
Make me know my transgression and my sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do You hide Your face,
And regard me as Your enemy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will You frighten a leaf driven to and fro?
And will You pursue dry stubble?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For You write bitter things against me,
And make me inherit the iniquities of my youth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You put my feet in the stocks,
And watch closely all my paths.
You set a limit for the soles of my feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Man decays like a rotten thing,
Like a garment that is moth-eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Man who is born of woman
Is of few days and full of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He comes forth like a flower and fades away;
He flees like a shadow and does not continue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And do You open Your eyes on such a one,
And bring me to judgment with Yourself?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can bring a clean thing out of an unclean?
No one!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Look away from him that he may rest,
Till like a hired man he finishes his day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For there is hope for a tree,
If it is cut down, that it will sprout again,
And that its tender shoots will not cease.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though its root may grow old in the earth,
And its stump may die in the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet at the scent of water it will bud
And bring forth branches like a plant.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
As water disappears from the sea,
And a river becomes parched and dries up,
speaker: Narrator

text:
So man lies down and does not rise.
Till the heavens are no more,
They will not awake
Nor be roused from their sleep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Oh, that You would hide me in the grave,
That You would conceal me until Your wrath is past,
That You would appoint me a set time, and remember me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a man dies, shall he live again?
All the days of my hard service I will wait,
Till my change comes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You shall call, and I will answer You;
You shall desire the work of Your hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For now You number my steps,
But do not watch over my sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My transgression is sealed up in a bag,
And You cover my iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But as a mountain falls and crumbles away,
And as a rock is moved from its place;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
You prevail forever against him, and he passes on;
You change his countenance and send him away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His sons come to honor, and he does not know it;
They are brought low, and he does not perceive it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But his flesh will be in pain over it,
And his soul will mourn over it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Should a wise man answer with empty knowledge,
And fill himself with the east wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should he reason with unprofitable talk,
Or by speeches with which he can do no good?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, you cast off fear,
And restrain prayer before God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For your iniquity teaches your mouth,
And you choose the tongue of the crafty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your own mouth condemns you, and not I;
Yes, your own lips testify against you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Are you the first man who was born?
Or were you made before the hills?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you heard the counsel of God?
Do you limit wisdom to yourself?
speaker: Narrator

text:
What do you know that we do not know?
What do you understand that is not in us?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Both the gray-haired and the aged are among us,
Much older than your father.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are the consolations of God too small for you,
And the word spoken gently with you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why does your heart carry you away,
And what do your eyes wink at,
speaker: Narrator

text:
That you turn your spirit against God,
And let such words go out of your mouth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What is man, that he could be pure?
And he who is born of a woman, that he could be righteous?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If God puts no trust in His saints,
And the heavens are not pure in His sight,
speaker: Narrator

text:
How much less man, who is abominable and filthy,
Who drinks iniquity like water!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will tell you, hear me;
What I have seen I will declare,
speaker: Narrator

text:
What wise men have told,
Not hiding anything received from their fathers,
speaker: Narrator

text:
To whom alone the land was given,
And no alien passed among them:
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked man writhes with pain all his days,
And the number of years is hidden from the oppressor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Dreadful sounds are in his ears;
In prosperity the destroyer comes upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He does not believe that he will return from darkness,
For a sword is waiting for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He wanders about for bread, saying, ‘Where is it?’
He knows that a day of darkness is ready at his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Trouble and anguish make him afraid;
They overpower him, like a king ready for battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he stretches out his hand against God,
And acts defiantly against the Almighty,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Running stubbornly against Him
With his strong, embossed shield.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Though he has covered his face with his fatness,
And made his waist heavy with fat,
speaker: Narrator

text:
He dwells in desolate cities,
In houses which no one inhabits,
Which are destined to become ruins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will not be rich,
Nor will his wealth continue,
Nor will his possessions overspread the earth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Let him not trust in futile things, deceiving himself,
For futility will be his reward.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It will be accomplished before his time,
And his branch will not be green.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will shake off his unripe grape like a vine,
And cast off his blossom like an olive tree.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the company of hypocrites will be barren,
And fire will consume the tents of bribery.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They conceive trouble and bring forth futility;
Their womb prepares deceit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I have heard many such things;
Miserable comforters are you all!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shall words of wind have an end?
Or what provokes you that you answer?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I also could speak as you do,
If your soul were in my soul’s place.
I could heap up words against you,
And shake my head at you;
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I would strengthen you with my mouth,
And the comfort of my lips would relieve your grief.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Though I speak, my grief is not relieved;
And if I remain silent, how am I eased?
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now He has worn me out;
You have made desolate all my company.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have shriveled me up,
And it is a witness against me;
My leanness rises up against me
And bears witness to my face.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They gape at me with their mouth,
They strike me reproachfully on the cheek,
They gather together against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God has delivered me to the ungodly,
And turned me over to the hands of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
He breaks me with wound upon wound;
He runs at me like a warrior.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I have sewn sackcloth over my skin,
And laid my head in the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My face is flushed from weeping,
And on my eyelids is the shadow of death;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Although no violence is in my hands,
And my prayer is pure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“O earth, do not cover my blood,
And let my cry have no resting place!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely even now my witness is in heaven,
And my evidence is on high.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My friends scorn me;
My eyes pour out tears to God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, that one might plead for a man with God,
As a man pleads for his neighbor!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For when a few years are finished,
I shall go the way of no return.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My spirit is broken,
My days are extinguished,
The grave is ready for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are not mockers with me?
And does not my eye dwell on their provocation?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now put down a pledge for me with Yourself.
Who is he who will shake hands with me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For You have hidden their heart from understanding;
Therefore You will not exalt them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who speaks flattery to his friends,
Even the eyes of his children will fail.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But He has made me a byword of the people,
And I have become one in whose face men spit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My eye has also grown dim because of sorrow,
And all my members are like shadows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Upright men are astonished at this,
And the innocent stirs himself up against the hypocrite.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet the righteous will hold to his way,
And he who has clean hands will be stronger and stronger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But please, come back again, all of you,
For I shall not find one wise man among you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My days are past,
My purposes are broken off,
Even the thoughts of my heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They change the night into day;
‘The light is near,’ they say, in the face of darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I wait for the grave as my house,
If I make my bed in the darkness,
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I say to corruption, ‘You are my father,’
And to the worm, ‘You are my mother and my sister,’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where then is my hope?
As for my hope, who can see it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will they go down to the gates of Sheol?
Shall we have rest together in the dust?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Bildad the Shuhite answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long till you put an end to words?
Gain understanding, and afterward we will speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why are we counted as beasts,
And regarded as stupid in your sight?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You who tear yourself in anger,
Shall the earth be forsaken for you?
Or shall the rock be removed from its place?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The light of the wicked indeed goes out,
And the flame of his fire does not shine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The light is dark in his tent,
And his lamp beside him is put out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The steps of his strength are shortened,
And his own counsel casts him down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he is cast into a net by his own feet,
And he walks into a snare.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The net takes him by the heel,
And a snare lays hold of him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A noose is hidden for him on the ground,
And a trap for him in the road.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terrors frighten him on every side,
And drive him to his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His strength is starved,
And destruction is ready at his side.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It devours patches of his skin;
The firstborn of death devours his limbs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is uprooted from the shelter of his tent,
And they parade him before the king of terrors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They dwell in his tent who are none of his;
Brimstone is scattered on his dwelling.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His roots are dried out below,
And his branch withers above.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The memory of him perishes from the earth,
And he has no name among the renowned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is driven from light into darkness,
And chased out of the world.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has neither son nor posterity among his people,
Nor any remaining in his dwellings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those in the west are astonished at his day,
As those in the east are frightened.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely such are the dwellings of the wicked,
And this is the place of him who does not know God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long will you torment my soul,
And break me in pieces with words?
speaker: Narrator

text:
These ten times you have reproached me;
You are not ashamed that you have wronged me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And if indeed I have erred,
My error remains with me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If indeed you exalt yourselves against me,
And plead my disgrace against me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Know then that God has wronged me,
And has surrounded me with His net.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I cry out concerning wrong, I am not heard.
If I cry aloud, there is no justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has fenced up my way, so that I cannot pass;
And He has set darkness in my paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has stripped me of my glory,
And taken the crown from my head.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
He has also kindled His wrath against me,
And He counts me as one of His enemies.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“He has removed my brothers far from me,
And my acquaintances are completely estranged from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My relatives have failed,
And my close friends have forgotten me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I call my servant, but he gives no answer;
I beg him with my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My breath is offensive to my wife,
And I am repulsive to the children of my own body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even young children despise me;
I arise, and they speak against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All my close friends abhor me,
And those whom I love have turned against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My bone clings to my skin and to my flesh,
And I have escaped by the skin of my teeth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have pity on me, have pity on me, O you my friends,
For the hand of God has struck me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you persecute me as God does,
And are not satisfied with my flesh?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Oh, that my words were written!
Oh, that they were inscribed in a book!
speaker: Narrator

text:
That they were engraved on a rock
With an iron pen and lead, forever!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I know that my Redeemer lives,
And He shall stand at last on the earth;
speaker: Narrator

text:
And after my skin is destroyed, this I know,
That in my flesh I shall see God,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whom I shall see for myself,
And my eyes shall behold, and not another.
How my heart yearns within me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you should say, ‘How shall we persecute him?’—
Since the root of the matter is found in me,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Then Zophar the Naamathite answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Therefore my anxious thoughts make me answer,
Because of the turmoil within me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have heard the rebuke that reproaches me,
And the spirit of my understanding causes me to answer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you not know this of old,
Since man was placed on earth,
speaker: Narrator

text:
That the triumphing of the wicked is short,
And the joy of the hypocrite is but for a moment?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though his haughtiness mounts up to the heavens,
And his head reaches to the clouds,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet he will perish forever like his own refuse;
Those who have seen him will say, ‘Where is he?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will fly away like a dream, and not be found;
Yes, he will be chased away like a vision of the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eye that saw him will see him no more,
Nor will his place behold him anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His children will seek the favor of the poor,
And his hands will restore his wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His bones are full of his youthful vigor,
But it will lie down with him in the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Though evil is sweet in his mouth,
And he hides it under his tongue,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though he spares it and does not forsake it,
But still keeps it in his mouth,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet his food in his stomach turns sour;
It becomes cobra venom within him.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
He will suck the poison of cobras;
The viper’s tongue will slay him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will not see the streams,
The rivers flowing with honey and cream.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will restore that for which he labored,
And will not swallow it down;
From the proceeds of business
He will get no enjoyment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he has oppressed and forsaken the poor,
He has violently seized a house which he did not build.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Because he knows no quietness in his heart,
He will not save anything he desires.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nothing is left for him to eat;
Therefore his well-being will not last.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In his self-sufficiency he will be in distress;
Every hand of misery will come against him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he is about to fill his stomach,
God will cast on him the fury of His wrath,
And will rain it on him while he is eating.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will flee from the iron weapon;
A bronze bow will pierce him through.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
The heavens will reveal his iniquity,
And the earth will rise up against him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The increase of his house will depart,
And his goods will flow away in the day of His wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the portion from God for a wicked man,
The heritage appointed to him by God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Listen carefully to my speech,
And let this be your consolation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bear with me that I may speak,
And after I have spoken, keep mocking.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“As for me, is my complaint against man?
And if it were, why should I not be impatient?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look at me and be astonished;
Put your hand over your mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even when I remember I am terrified,
And trembling takes hold of my flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do the wicked live and become old,
Yes, become mighty in power?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their descendants are established with them in their sight,
And their offspring before their eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their houses are safe from fear,
Neither is the rod of God upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their bull breeds without failure;
Their cow calves without miscarriage.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They send forth their little ones like a flock,
And their children dance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They sing to the tambourine and harp,
And rejoice to the sound of the flute.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They spend their days in wealth,
And in a moment go down to the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet they say to God, ‘Depart from us,
For we do not desire the knowledge of Your ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is the Almighty, that we should serve Him?
And what profit do we have if we pray to Him?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed their prosperity is not in their hand;
The counsel of the wicked is far from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How often is the lamp of the wicked put out?
How often does their destruction come upon them,
The sorrows God distributes in His anger?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are like straw before the wind,
And like chaff that a storm carries away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They say, ‘God lays up one’s iniquity for his children’;
Let Him recompense him, that he may know it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let his eyes see his destruction,
And let him drink of the wrath of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For what does he care about his household after him,
When the number of his months is cut in half?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can anyone teach God knowledge,
Since He judges those on high?
speaker: Narrator

text:
One dies in his full strength,
Being wholly at ease and secure;
speaker: Narrator

text:
His pails are full of milk,
And the marrow of his bones is moist.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Another man dies in the bitterness of his soul,
Never having eaten with pleasure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They lie down alike in the dust,
And worms cover them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look, I know your thoughts,
And the schemes with which you would wrong me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you say,
‘Where is the house of the prince?
And where is the tent,
The dwelling place of the wicked?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you not asked those who travel the road?
And do you not know their signs?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the wicked are reserved for the day of doom;
They shall be brought out on the day of wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who condemns his way to his face?
And who repays him for what he has done?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet he shall be brought to the grave,
And a vigil kept over the tomb.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
How then can you comfort me with empty words,
Since falsehood remains in your answers?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can a man be profitable to God,
Though he who is wise may be profitable to himself?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it any pleasure to the Almighty that you are righteous?
Or is it gain to Him that you make your ways blameless?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Is it because of your fear of Him that He corrects you,
And enters into judgment with you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is not your wickedness great,
And your iniquity without end?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you have taken pledges from your brother for no reason,
And stripped the naked of their clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have not given the weary water to drink,
And you have withheld bread from the hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the mighty man possessed the land,
And the honorable man dwelt in it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have sent widows away empty,
And the strength of the fatherless was crushed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore snares are all around you,
And sudden fear troubles you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or darkness so that you cannot see;
And an abundance of water covers you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Is not God in the height of heaven?
And see the highest stars, how lofty they are!
speaker: Narrator

text:
And you say, ‘What does God know?
Can He judge through the deep darkness?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thick clouds cover Him, so that He cannot see,
And He walks above the circle of heaven.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you keep to the old way
Which wicked men have trod,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who were cut down before their time,
Whose foundations were swept away by a flood?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They said to God, ‘Depart from us!
What can the Almighty do to them?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet He filled their houses with good things;
But the counsel of the wicked is far from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The righteous see it and are glad,
And the innocent laugh at them:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Surely our adversaries are cut down,
And the fire consumes their remnant.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now acquaint yourself with Him, and be at peace;
Thereby good will come to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Receive, please, instruction from His mouth,
And lay up His words in your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you return to the Almighty, you will be built up;
You will remove iniquity far from your tents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will lay your gold in the dust,
And the gold of Ophir among the stones of the brooks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, the Almighty will be your gold
And your precious silver;
speaker: Narrator

text:
For then you will have your delight in the Almighty,
And lift up your face to God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will make your prayer to Him,
He will hear you,
And you will pay your vows.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
When they cast you down, and you say, ‘Exaltation will come!’
Then He will save the humble person.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will even deliver one who is not innocent;
Yes, he will be delivered by the purity of your hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Even today my complaint is bitter;
My hand is listless because of my groaning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, that I knew where I might find Him,
That I might come to His seat!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would present my case before Him,
And fill my mouth with arguments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would know the words which He would answer me,
And understand what He would say to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Would He contend with me in His great power?
No! But He would take note of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There the upright could reason with Him,
And I would be delivered forever from my Judge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look, I go forward, but He is not there,
And backward, but I cannot perceive Him;
speaker: Narrator

text:
When He works on the left hand, I cannot behold Him;
When He turns to the right hand, I cannot see Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But He knows the way that I take;
When He has tested me, I shall come forth as gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My foot has held fast to His steps;
I have kept His way and not turned aside.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“But He is unique, and who can make Him change?
And whatever His soul desires, that He does.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He performs what is appointed for me,
And many such things are with Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I am terrified at His presence;
When I consider this, I am afraid of Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For God made my heart weak,
And the Almighty terrifies me;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because I was not cut off from the presence of darkness,
And He did not hide deep darkness from my face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Since times are not hidden from the Almighty,
Why do those who know Him see not His days?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Some remove landmarks;
They seize flocks violently and feed on them;
speaker: Narrator

text:
They drive away the donkey of the fatherless;
They take the widow’s ox as a pledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They push the needy off the road;
All the poor of the land are forced to hide.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, like wild donkeys in the desert,
They go out to their work, searching for food.
The wilderness yields food for them and for their children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They gather their fodder in the field
And glean in the vineyard of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They spend the night naked, without clothing,
And have no covering in the cold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are wet with the showers of the mountains,
And huddle around the rock for want of shelter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Some snatch the fatherless from the breast,
And take a pledge from the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They cause the poor to go naked, without clothing;
And they take away the sheaves from the hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They press out oil within their walls,
And tread winepresses, yet suffer thirst.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
“They should be swift on the face of the waters,
Their portion should be cursed in the earth,
So that no one would turn into the way of their vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As drought and heat consume the snow waters,
So the grave consumes those who have sinned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The womb should forget him,
The worm should feed sweetly on him;
He should be remembered no more,
And wickedness should be broken like a tree.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he preys on the barren who do not bear,
And does no good for the widow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But God draws the mighty away with His power;
He rises up, but no man is sure of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He gives them security, and they rely on it;
Yet His eyes are on their ways.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Now if it is not so, who will prove me a liar,
And make my speech worth nothing?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Bildad the Shuhite answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Dominion and fear belong to Him;
He makes peace in His high places.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is there any number to His armies?
Upon whom does His light not rise?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How then can man be righteous before God?
Or how can he be pure who is born of a woman?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If even the moon does not shine,
And the stars are not pure in His sight,
speaker: Narrator

text:
How much less man, who is a maggot,
And a son of man, who is a worm?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Job answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How have you helped him who is without power?
How have you saved the arm that has no strength?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How have you counseled one who has no wisdom?
And how have you declared sound advice to many?
speaker: Narrator

text:
To whom have you uttered words?
And whose spirit came from you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The dead tremble,
Those under the waters and those inhabiting them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sheol is naked before Him,
And Destruction has no covering.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He stretches out the north over empty space;
He hangs the earth on nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He binds up the water in His thick clouds,
Yet the clouds are not broken under it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He covers the face of His throne,
And spreads His cloud over it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He drew a circular horizon on the face of the waters,
At the boundary of light and darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The pillars of heaven tremble,
And are astonished at His rebuke.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He stirs up the sea with His power,
And by His understanding He breaks up the storm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By His Spirit He adorned the heavens;
His hand pierced the fleeing serpent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed these are the mere edges of His ways,
And how small a whisper we hear of Him!
But the thunder of His power who can understand?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover Job continued his discourse, and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“As God lives, who has taken away my justice,
And the Almighty, who has made my soul bitter,
speaker: Narrator

text:
As long as my breath is in me,
And the breath of God in my nostrils,
speaker: Narrator

text:
My lips will not speak wickedness,
Nor my tongue utter deceit.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
My righteousness I hold fast, and will not let it go;
My heart shall not reproach me as long as I live.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“May my enemy be like the wicked,
And he who rises up against me like the unrighteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For what is the hope of the hypocrite,
Though he may gain much,
If God takes away his life?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will God hear his cry
When trouble comes upon him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he delight himself in the Almighty?
Will he always call on God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will teach you about the hand of God;
What is with the Almighty I will not conceal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely all of you have seen it;
Why then do you behave with complete nonsense?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This is the portion of a wicked man with God,
And the heritage of oppressors, received from the Almighty:
speaker: Narrator

text:
If his children are multiplied, it is for the sword;
And his offspring shall not be satisfied with bread.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who survive him shall be buried in death,
And their widows shall not weep,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though he heaps up silver like dust,
And piles up clothing like clay—
speaker: Narrator

text:
He may pile it up, but the just will wear it,
And the innocent will divide the silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He builds his house like a moth,
Like a booth which a watchman makes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rich man will lie down,
But not be gathered up;
He opens his eyes,
And he is no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terrors overtake him like a flood;
A tempest steals him away in the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The east wind carries him away, and he is gone;
It sweeps him out of his place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It hurls against him and does not spare;
He flees desperately from its power.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Men shall clap their hands at him,
And shall hiss him out of his place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Surely there is a mine for silver,
And a place where gold is refined.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Iron is taken from the earth,
And copper is smelted from ore.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Man puts an end to darkness,
And searches every recess
For ore in the darkness and the shadow of death.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
As for the earth, from it comes bread,
But underneath it is turned up as by fire;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its stones are the source of sapphires,
And it contains gold dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That path no bird knows,
Nor has the falcon’s eye seen it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The proud lions have not trodden it,
Nor has the fierce lion passed over it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He puts his hand on the flint;
He overturns the mountains at the roots.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He cuts out channels in the rocks,
And his eye sees every precious thing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He dams up the streams from trickling;
What is hidden he brings forth to light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But where can wisdom be found?
And where is the place of understanding?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Man does not know its value,
Nor is it found in the land of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The deep says, ‘It is not in me’;
And the sea says, ‘It is not with me.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
It cannot be purchased for gold,
Nor can silver be weighed for its price.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It cannot be valued in the gold of Ophir,
In precious onyx or sapphire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Neither gold nor crystal can equal it,
Nor can it be exchanged for jewelry of fine gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No mention shall be made of coral or quartz,
For the price of wisdom is above rubies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The topaz of Ethiopia cannot equal it,
Nor can it be valued in pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“From where then does wisdom come?
And where is the place of understanding?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is hidden from the eyes of all living,
And concealed from the birds of the air.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Destruction and Death say,
‘We have heard a report about it with our ears.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
God understands its way,
And He knows its place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He looks to the ends of the earth,
And sees under the whole heavens,
speaker: Narrator

text:
To establish a weight for the wind,
And apportion the waters by measure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When He made a law for the rain,
And a path for the thunderbolt,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then He saw wisdom and declared it;
He prepared it, indeed, He searched it out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And to man He said,
‘Behold, the fear of the Lord, that is wisdom,
And to depart from evil is understanding.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Job further continued his discourse, and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Oh, that I were as in months past,
As in the days when God watched over me;
speaker: Narrator

text:
When His lamp shone upon my head,
And when by His light I walked through darkness;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just as I was in the days of my prime,
When the friendly counsel of God was over my tent;
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Almighty was yet with me,
When my children were around me;
speaker: Narrator

text:
When my steps were bathed with cream,
And the rock poured out rivers of oil for me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When I went out to the gate by the city,
When I took my seat in the open square,
speaker: Narrator

text:
The young men saw me and hid,
And the aged arose and stood;
speaker: Narrator

text:
The princes refrained from talking,
And put their hand on their mouth;
speaker: Narrator

text:
The voice of nobles was hushed,
And their tongue stuck to the roof of their mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the ear heard, then it blessed me,
And when the eye saw, then it approved me;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because I delivered the poor who cried out,
The fatherless and the one who had no helper.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The blessing of a perishing man came upon me,
And I caused the widow’s heart to sing for joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I put on righteousness, and it clothed me;
My justice was like a robe and a turban.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was eyes to the blind,
And I was feet to the lame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was a father to the poor,
And I searched out the case that I did not know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I broke the fangs of the wicked,
And plucked the victim from his teeth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Then I said, ‘I shall die in my nest,
And multiply my days as the sand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My root is spread out to the waters,
And the dew lies all night on my branch.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My glory is fresh within me,
And my bow is renewed in my hand.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Men listened to me and waited,
And kept silence for my counsel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After my words they did not speak again,
And my speech settled on them as dew.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They waited for me as for the rain,
And they opened their mouth wide as for the spring rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I mocked at them, they did not believe it,
And the light of my countenance they did not cast down.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“But now they mock at me, men younger than I,
Whose fathers I disdained to put with the dogs of my flock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, what profit is the strength of their hands to me?
Their vigor has perished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are gaunt from want and famine,
Fleeing late to the wilderness, desolate and waste,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who pluck mallow by the bushes,
And broom tree roots for their food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were driven out from among men,
They shouted at them as at a thief.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They had to live in the clefts of the valleys,
In caves of the earth and the rocks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Among the bushes they brayed,
Under the nettles they nestled.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“And now I am their taunting song;
Yes, I am their byword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They abhor me, they keep far from me;
They do not hesitate to spit in my face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because He has loosed my bowstring and afflicted me,
They have cast off restraint before me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
They come as broad breakers;
Under the ruinous storm they roll along.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“And now my soul is poured out because of my plight;
The days of affliction take hold of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My bones are pierced in me at night,
And my gnawing pains take no rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By great force my garment is disfigured;
It binds me about as the collar of my coat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has cast me into the mire,
And I have become like dust and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I cry out to You, but You do not answer me;
I stand up, and You regard me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But You have become cruel to me;
With the strength of Your hand You oppose me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You lift me up to the wind and cause me to ride on it;
You spoil my success.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I know that You will bring me to death,
And to the house appointed for all living.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Surely He would not stretch out His hand against a heap of ruins,
If they cry out when He destroys it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have I not wept for him who was in trouble?
Has not my soul grieved for the poor?
speaker: Narrator

text:
But when I looked for good, evil came to me;
And when I waited for light, then came darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My heart is in turmoil and cannot rest;
Days of affliction confront me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I go about mourning, but not in the sun;
I stand up in the assembly and cry out for help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am a brother of jackals,
And a companion of ostriches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My skin grows black and falls from me;
My bones burn with fever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My harp is turned to mourning,
And my flute to the voice of those who weep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I have made a covenant with my eyes;
Why then should I look upon a young woman?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For what is the allotment of God from above,
And the inheritance of the Almighty from on high?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it not destruction for the wicked,
And disaster for the workers of iniquity?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does He not see my ways,
And count all my steps?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have walked with falsehood,
Or if my foot has hastened to deceit,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let me be weighed on honest scales,
That God may know my integrity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If my step has turned from the way,
Or my heart walked after my eyes,
Or if any spot adheres to my hands,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then let me sow, and another eat;
Yes, let my harvest be rooted out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If my heart has been enticed by a woman,
Or if I have lurked at my neighbor’s door,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then let my wife grind for another,
And let others bow down over her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For that would be wickedness;
Yes, it would be iniquity deserving of judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For that would be a fire that consumes to destruction,
And would root out all my increase.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have despised the cause of my male or female servant
When they complained against me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
What then shall I do when God rises up?
When He punishes, how shall I answer Him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did not He who made me in the womb make them?
Did not the same One fashion us in the womb?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have kept the poor from their desire,
Or caused the eyes of the widow to fail,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or eaten my morsel by myself,
So that the fatherless could not eat of it
speaker: Narrator

text:
(But from my youth I reared him as a father,
And from my mother’s womb I guided the widow);
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have seen anyone perish for lack of clothing,
Or any poor man without covering;
speaker: Narrator

text:
If his heart has not blessed me,
And if he was not warmed with the fleece of my sheep;
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have raised my hand against the fatherless,
When I saw I had help in the gate;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then let my arm fall from my shoulder,
Let my arm be torn from the socket.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For destruction from God is a terror to me,
And because of His magnificence I cannot endure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have made gold my hope,
Or said to fine gold, ‘You are my confidence’;
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have rejoiced because my wealth was great,
And because my hand had gained much;
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have observed the sun when it shines,
Or the moon moving in brightness,
speaker: Narrator

text:
So that my heart has been secretly enticed,
And my mouth has kissed my hand;
speaker: Narrator

text:
This also would be an iniquity deserving of judgment,
For I would have denied God who is above.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have rejoiced at the destruction of him who hated me,
Or lifted myself up when evil found him
speaker: Narrator

text:
(Indeed I have not allowed my mouth to sin
By asking for a curse on his soul);
speaker: Narrator

text:
If the men of my tent have not said,
‘Who is there that has not been satisfied with his meat?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
(But no sojourner had to lodge in the street,
For I have opened my doors to the traveler);
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have covered my transgressions as Adam,
By hiding my iniquity in my bosom,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because I feared the great multitude,
And dreaded the contempt of families,
So that I kept silence
And did not go out of the door—
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, that I had one to hear me!
Here is my mark.
Oh, that the Almighty would answer me,
That my Prosecutor had written a book!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely I would carry it on my shoulder,
And bind it on me like a crown;
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would declare to Him the number of my steps;
Like a prince I would approach Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If my land cries out against me,
And its furrows weep together;
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have eaten its fruit without money,
Or caused its owners to lose their lives;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then let thistles grow instead of wheat,
And weeds instead of barley.”
The words of Job are ended.
speaker: Narrator

text: So these three men ceased answering Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the wrath of Elihu, the son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, was aroused against Job; his wrath was aroused because he justified himself rather than God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also against his three friends his wrath was aroused, because they had found no answer, and yet had condemned Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now because they were years older than he, Elihu had waited to speak to Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elihu saw that there was no answer in the mouth of these three men, his wrath was aroused.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Elihu, the son of Barachel the Buzite, answered and said:
“I am young in years, and you are very old;
Therefore I was afraid,
And dared not declare my opinion to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, ‘Age should speak,
And multitude of years should teach wisdom.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But there is a spirit in man,
And the breath of the Almighty gives him understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Great men are not always wise,
Nor do the aged always understand justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Therefore I say, ‘Listen to me,
I also will declare my opinion.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed I waited for your words,
I listened to your reasonings, while you searched out what to say.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Now he has not directed his words against me;
So I will not answer him with your words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They are dismayed and answer no more;
Words escape them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I have waited, because they did not speak,
Because they stood still and answered no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I also will answer my part,
I too will declare my opinion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I am full of words;
The spirit within me compels me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed my belly is like wine that has no vent;
It is ready to burst like new wineskins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will speak, that I may find relief;
I must open my lips and answer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let me not, I pray, show partiality to anyone;
Nor let me flatter any man.
