speaker: Narrator

text:
For I do not know how to flatter,
Else my Maker would soon take me away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But please, Job, hear my speech,
And listen to all my words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now, I open my mouth;
My tongue speaks in my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My words come from my upright heart;
My lips utter pure knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Spirit of God has made me,
And the breath of the Almighty gives me life.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Truly I am as your spokesman before God;
I also have been formed out of clay.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely no fear of me will terrify you,
Nor will my hand be heavy on you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Surely you have spoken in my hearing,
And I have heard the sound of your words, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘I am pure, without transgression;
I am innocent, and there is no iniquity in me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet He finds occasions against me,
He counts me as His enemy;
speaker: Narrator

text:
He puts my feet in the stocks,
He watches all my paths.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look, in this you are not righteous.
I will answer you,
For God is greater than man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you contend with Him?
For He does not give an accounting of any of His words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For God may speak in one way, or in another,
Yet man does not perceive it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In a dream, in a vision of the night,
When deep sleep falls upon men,
While slumbering on their beds,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then He opens the ears of men,
And seals their instruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In order to turn man from his deed,
And conceal pride from man,
speaker: Narrator

text:
He keeps back his soul from the Pit,
And his life from perishing by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Man is also chastened with pain on his bed,
And with strong pain in many of his bones,
speaker: Narrator

text:
So that his life abhors bread,
And his soul succulent food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His flesh wastes away from sight,
And his bones stick out which once were not seen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, his soul draws near the Pit,
And his life to the executioners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If there is a messenger for him,
A mediator, one among a thousand,
To show man His uprightness,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
His flesh shall be young like a child’s,
He shall return to the days of his youth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall pray to God, and He will delight in him,
He shall see His face with joy,
For He restores to man His righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he looks at men and says,
‘I have sinned, and perverted what was right,
And it did not profit me.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will redeem his soul from going down to the Pit,
And his life shall see the light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, God works all these things,
Twice, in fact, three times with a man,
speaker: Narrator

text:
To bring back his soul from the Pit,
That he may be enlightened with the light of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Give ear, Job, listen to me;
Hold your peace, and I will speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you have anything to say, answer me;
Speak, for I desire to justify you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If not, listen to me;
Hold your peace, and I will teach you wisdom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihu further answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Hear my words, you wise men;
Give ear to me, you who have knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the ear tests words
As the palate tastes food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let us choose justice for ourselves;
Let us know among ourselves what is good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For Job has said, ‘I am righteous,
But God has taken away my justice;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should I lie concerning my right?
My wound is incurable, though I am without transgression.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
What man is like Job,
Who drinks scorn like water,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who goes in company with the workers of iniquity,
And walks with wicked men?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he has said, ‘It profits a man nothing
That he should delight in God.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Therefore listen to me, you men of understanding:
Far be it from God to do wickedness,
And from the Almighty to commit iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He repays man according to his work,
And makes man to find a reward according to his way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely God will never do wickedly,
Nor will the Almighty pervert justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who gave Him charge over the earth?
Or who appointed Him over the whole world?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If He should set His heart on it,
If He should gather to Himself His Spirit and His breath,
speaker: Narrator

text:
All flesh would perish together,
And man would return to dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If you have understanding, hear this;
Listen to the sound of my words:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should one who hates justice govern?
Will you condemn Him who is most just?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it fitting to say to a king, ‘You are worthless,’
And to nobles, ‘You are wicked’?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
“For His eyes are on the ways of man,
And He sees all his steps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is no darkness nor shadow of death
Where the workers of iniquity may hide themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He need not further consider a man,
That he should go before God in judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He breaks in pieces mighty men without inquiry,
And sets others in their place.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
He strikes them as wicked men
In the open sight of others,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because they turned back from Him,
And would not consider any of His ways,
speaker: Narrator

text:
So that they caused the cry of the poor to come to Him;
For He hears the cry of the afflicted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When He gives quietness, who then can make trouble?
And when He hides His face, who then can see Him,
Whether it is against a nation or a man alone?—
speaker: Narrator

text:
That the hypocrite should not reign,
Lest the people be ensnared.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Teach me what I do not see;
If I have done iniquity, I will do no more’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should He repay it according to your terms,
Just because you disavow it?
You must choose, and not I;
Therefore speak what you know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Men of understanding say to me,
Wise men who listen to me:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Job speaks without knowledge,
His words are without wisdom.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, that Job were tried to the utmost,
Because his answers are like those of wicked men!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Moreover Elihu answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you think this is right?
Do you say,
‘My righteousness is more than God’s’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you say,
‘What advantage will it be to You?
What profit shall I have, more than if I had sinned?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will answer you,
And your companions with you.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
If you sin, what do you accomplish against Him?
Or, if your transgressions are multiplied, what do you do to Him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you are righteous, what do you give Him?
Or what does He receive from your hand?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your wickedness affects a man such as you,
And your righteousness a son of man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Because of the multitude of oppressions they cry out;
They cry out for help because of the arm of the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But no one says, ‘Where is God my Maker,
Who gives songs in the night,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who teaches us more than the beasts of the earth,
And makes us wiser than the birds of heaven?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
There they cry out, but He does not answer,
Because of the pride of evil men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely God will not listen to empty talk,
Nor will the Almighty regard it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Although you say you do not see Him,
Yet justice is before Him, and you must wait for Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And now, because He has not punished in His anger,
Nor taken much notice of folly,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore Job opens his mouth in vain;
He multiplies words without knowledge.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihu also proceeded and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Bear with me a little, and I will show you
That there are yet words to speak on God’s behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will fetch my knowledge from afar;
I will ascribe righteousness to my Maker.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For truly my words are not false;
One who is perfect in knowledge is with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, God is mighty, but despises no one;
He is mighty in strength of understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He does not preserve the life of the wicked,
But gives justice to the oppressed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He does not withdraw His eyes from the righteous;
But they are on the throne with kings,
For He has seated them forever,
And they are exalted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And if they are bound in fetters,
Held in the cords of affliction,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then He tells them their work and their transgressions—
That they have acted defiantly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He also opens their ear to instruction,
And commands that they turn from iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If they obey and serve Him,
They shall spend their days in prosperity,
And their years in pleasures.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But if they do not obey,
They shall perish by the sword,
And they shall die without knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But the hypocrites in heart store up wrath;
They do not cry for help when He binds them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They die in youth,
And their life ends among the perverted persons.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He delivers the poor in their affliction,
And opens their ears in oppression.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
But you are filled with the judgment due the wicked;
Judgment and justice take hold of you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because there is wrath, beware lest He take you away with one blow;
For a large ransom would not help you avoid it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will your riches,
Or all the mighty forces,
Keep you from distress?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not desire the night,
When people are cut off in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take heed, do not turn to iniquity,
For you have chosen this rather than affliction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, God is exalted by His power;
Who teaches like Him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has assigned Him His way,
Or who has said, ‘You have done wrong’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Remember to magnify His work,
Of which men have sung.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Everyone has seen it;
Man looks on it from afar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, God is great, and we do not know Him;
Nor can the number of His years be discovered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He draws up drops of water,
Which distill as rain from the mist,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which the clouds drop down
And pour abundantly on man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, can anyone understand the spreading of clouds,
The thunder from His canopy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, He scatters His light upon it,
And covers the depths of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For by these He judges the peoples;
He gives food in abundance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He covers His hands with lightning,
And commands it to strike.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His thunder declares it,
The cattle also, concerning the rising storm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“At this also my heart trembles,
And leaps from its place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear attentively the thunder of His voice,
And the rumbling that comes from His mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sends it forth under the whole heaven,
His lightning to the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
God thunders marvelously with His voice;
He does great things which we cannot comprehend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He says to the snow, ‘Fall on the earth’;
Likewise to the gentle rain and the heavy rain of His strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He seals the hand of every man,
That all men may know His work.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The beasts go into dens,
And remain in their lairs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the chamber of the south comes the whirlwind,
And cold from the scattering winds of the north.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the breath of God ice is given,
And the broad waters are frozen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Also with moisture He saturates the thick clouds;
He scatters His bright clouds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And they swirl about, being turned by His guidance,
That they may do whatever He commands them
On the face of the whole earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He causes it to come,
Whether for correction,
Or for His land,
Or for mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Listen to this, O Job;
Stand still and consider the wondrous works of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know when God dispatches them,
And causes the light of His cloud to shine?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know how the clouds are balanced,
Those wondrous works of Him who is perfect in knowledge?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why are your garments hot,
When He quiets the earth by the south wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
With Him, have you spread out the skies,
Strong as a cast metal mirror?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Teach us what we should say to Him,
For we can prepare nothing because of the darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should He be told that I wish to speak?
If a man were to speak, surely he would be swallowed up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even now men cannot look at the light when it is bright in the skies,
When the wind has passed and cleared them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He comes from the north as golden splendor;
With God is awesome majesty.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Therefore men fear Him;
He shows no partiality to any who are wise of heart.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord answered Job out of the whirlwind, and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who is this who darkens counsel
By words without knowledge?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now prepare yourself like a man;
I will question you, and you shall answer Me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where were you when I laid the foundations of the earth?
Tell Me, if you have understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who determined its measurements?
Surely you know!
Or who stretched the line upon it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
To what were its foundations fastened?
Or who laid its cornerstone,
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the morning stars sang together,
And all the sons of God shouted for joy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Or who shut in the sea with doors,
When it burst forth and issued from the womb;
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I made the clouds its garment,
And thick darkness its swaddling band;
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I fixed My limit for it,
And set bars and doors;
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I said,
‘This far you may come, but no farther,
And here your proud waves must stop!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you commanded the morning since your days began,
And caused the dawn to know its place,
speaker: Narrator

text:
That it might take hold of the ends of the earth,
And the wicked be shaken out of it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It takes on form like clay under a seal,
And stands out like a garment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the wicked their light is withheld,
And the upraised arm is broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you entered the springs of the sea?
Or have you walked in search of the depths?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have the gates of death been revealed to you?
Or have you seen the doors of the shadow of death?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you comprehended the breadth of the earth?
Tell Me, if you know all this.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where is the way to the dwelling of light?
And darkness, where is its place,
speaker: Narrator

text:
That you may take it to its territory,
That you may know the paths to its home?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know it, because you were born then,
Or because the number of your days is great?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you entered the treasury of snow,
Or have you seen the treasury of hail,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which I have reserved for the time of trouble,
For the day of battle and war?
speaker: Narrator

text:
By what way is light diffused,
Or the east wind scattered over the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who has divided a channel for the overflowing water,
Or a path for the thunderbolt,
speaker: Narrator

text:
To cause it to rain on a land where there is no one,
A wilderness in which there is no man;
speaker: Narrator

text:
To satisfy the desolate waste,
And cause to spring forth the growth of tender grass?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Has the rain a father?
Or who has begotten the drops of dew?
speaker: Narrator

text:
From whose womb comes the ice?
And the frost of heaven, who gives it birth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The waters harden like stone,
And the surface of the deep is frozen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you bind the cluster of the Pleiades,
Or loose the belt of Orion?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you bring out Mazzaroth in its season?
Or can you guide the Great Bear with its cubs?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know the ordinances of the heavens?
Can you set their dominion over the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you lift up your voice to the clouds,
That an abundance of water may cover you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you send out lightnings, that they may go,
And say to you, ‘Here we are!’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has put wisdom in the mind?
Or who has given understanding to the heart?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can number the clouds by wisdom?
Or who can pour out the bottles of heaven,
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the dust hardens in clumps,
And the clods cling together?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you hunt the prey for the lion,
Or satisfy the appetite of the young lions,
speaker: Narrator

text:
When they crouch in their dens,
Or lurk in their lairs to lie in wait?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who provides food for the raven,
When its young ones cry to God,
And wander about for lack of food?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you know the time when the wild mountain goats bear young?
Or can you mark when the deer gives birth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you number the months that they fulfill?
Or do you know the time when they bear young?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They bow down,
They bring forth their young,
They deliver their offspring.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Who set the wild donkey free?
Who loosed the bonds of the onager,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whose home I have made the wilderness,
And the barren land his dwelling?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He scorns the tumult of the city;
He does not heed the shouts of the driver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The range of the mountains is his pasture,
And he searches after every green thing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Will the wild ox be willing to serve you?
Will he bed by your manger?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you bind the wild ox in the furrow with ropes?
Or will he plow the valleys behind you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you trust him because his strength is great?
Or will you leave your labor to him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you trust him to bring home your grain,
And gather it to your threshing floor?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The wings of the ostrich wave proudly,
But are her wings and pinions like the kindly stork’s?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For she leaves her eggs on the ground,
And warms them in the dust;
speaker: Narrator

text:
She forgets that a foot may crush them,
Or that a wild beast may break them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She treats her young harshly, as though they were not hers;
Her labor is in vain, without concern,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because God deprived her of wisdom,
And did not endow her with understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When she lifts herself on high,
She scorns the horse and its rider.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you given the horse strength?
Have you clothed his neck with thunder?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you frighten him like a locust?
His majestic snorting strikes terror.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He paws in the valley, and rejoices in his strength;
He gallops into the clash of arms.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He mocks at fear, and is not frightened;
Nor does he turn back from the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The quiver rattles against him,
The glittering spear and javelin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He devours the distance with fierceness and rage;
Nor does he come to a halt because the trumpet has sounded.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At the blast of the trumpet he says, ‘Aha!’
He smells the battle from afar,
The thunder of captains and shouting.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Does the hawk fly by your wisdom,
And spread its wings toward the south?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does the eagle mount up at your command,
And make its nest on high?
speaker: Narrator

text:
On the rock it dwells and resides,
On the crag of the rock and the stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From there it spies out the prey;
Its eyes observe from afar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its young ones suck up blood;
And where the slain are, there it is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover the Lord answered Job, and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Shall the one who contends with the Almighty correct Him?
He who rebukes God, let him answer it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered the Lord and said:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Once I have spoken, but I will not answer;
Yes, twice, but I will proceed no further.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord answered Job out of the whirlwind, and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now prepare yourself like a man;
I will question you, and you shall answer Me:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Would you indeed annul My judgment?
Would you condemn Me that you may be justified?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you an arm like God?
Or can you thunder with a voice like His?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then adorn yourself with majesty and splendor,
And array yourself with glory and beauty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Disperse the rage of your wrath;
Look on everyone who is proud, and humble him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look on everyone who is proud, and bring him low;
Tread down the wicked in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hide them in the dust together,
Bind their faces in hidden darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I will also confess to you
That your own right hand can save you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look now at the behemoth, which I made along with you;
He eats grass like an ox.
speaker: Narrator

text:
See now, his strength is in his hips,
And his power is in his stomach muscles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He moves his tail like a cedar;
The sinews of his thighs are tightly knit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His bones are like beams of bronze,
His ribs like bars of iron.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is the first of the ways of God;
Only He who made him can bring near His sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely the mountains yield food for him,
And all the beasts of the field play there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He lies under the lotus trees,
In a covert of reeds and marsh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lotus trees cover him with their shade;
The willows by the brook surround him.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Though he takes it in his eyes,
Or one pierces his nose with a snare.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you draw out Leviathan with a hook,
Or snare his tongue with a line which you lower?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you put a reed through his nose,
Or pierce his jaw with a hook?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he make many supplications to you?
Will he speak softly to you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he make a covenant with you?
Will you take him as a servant forever?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you play with him as with a bird,
Or will you leash him for your maidens?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will your companions make a banquet of him?
Will they apportion him among the merchants?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you fill his skin with harpoons,
Or his head with fishing spears?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Indeed, any hope of overcoming him is false;
Shall one not be overwhelmed at the sight of him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
No one is so fierce that he would dare stir him up.
Who then is able to stand against Me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has preceded Me, that I should pay him?
Everything under heaven is Mine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will not conceal his limbs,
His mighty power, or his graceful proportions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can remove his outer coat?
Who can approach him with a double bridle?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can open the doors of his face,
With his terrible teeth all around?
speaker: Narrator

text:
His rows of scales are his pride,
Shut up tightly as with a seal;
speaker: Narrator

text:
One is so near another
That no air can come between them;
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are joined one to another,
They stick together and cannot be parted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His sneezings flash forth light,
And his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of his mouth go burning lights;
Sparks of fire shoot out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Smoke goes out of his nostrils,
As from a boiling pot and burning rushes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His breath kindles coals,
And a flame goes out of his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Strength dwells in his neck,
And sorrow dances before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The folds of his flesh are joined together;
They are firm on him and cannot be moved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His heart is as hard as stone,
Even as hard as the lower millstone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he raises himself up, the mighty are afraid;
Because of his crashings they are beside themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though the sword reaches him, it cannot avail;
Nor does spear, dart, or javelin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He regards iron as straw,
And bronze as rotten wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The arrow cannot make him flee;
Slingstones become like stubble to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Darts are regarded as straw;
He laughs at the threat of javelins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His undersides are like sharp potsherds;
He spreads pointed marks in the mire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He makes the deep boil like a pot;
He makes the sea like a pot of ointment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He leaves a shining wake behind him;
One would think the deep had white hair.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On earth there is nothing like him,
Which is made without fear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He beholds every high thing;
He is king over all the children of pride.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered the Lord and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I know that You can do everything,
And that no purpose of Yours can be withheld from You.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You asked, ‘Who is this who hides counsel without knowledge?’
Therefore I have uttered what I did not understand,
Things too wonderful for me, which I did not know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen, please, and let me speak;
You said, ‘I will question you, and you shall answer Me.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I have heard of You by the hearing of the ear,
But now my eye sees You.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I abhor myself,
And repent in dust and ashes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And so it was, after the Lord had spoken these words to Job, that the Lord said to Eliphaz the Temanite, “My wrath is aroused against you and your two friends, for you have not spoken of Me what is right, as My servant Job has.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, take for yourselves seven bulls and seven rams, go to My servant Job, and offer up for yourselves a burnt offering; and My servant Job shall pray for you. For I will accept him, lest I deal with you according to your folly; because you have not spoken of Me what is right, as My servant Job has.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Eliphaz the Temanite and Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite went and did as the Lord commanded them; for the Lord had accepted Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord restored Job’s losses when he prayed for his friends. Indeed the Lord gave Job twice as much as he had before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all his brothers, all his sisters, and all those who had been his acquaintances before, came to him and ate food with him in his house; and they consoled him and comforted him for all the adversity that the Lord had brought upon him. Each one gave him a piece of silver and each a ring of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord blessed the latter days of Job more than his beginning; for he had fourteen thousand sheep, six thousand camels, one thousand yoke of oxen, and one thousand female donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also had seven sons and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he called the name of the first Jemimah, the name of the second Keziah, and the name of the third Keren-Happuch.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all the land were found no women so beautiful as the daughters of Job; and their father gave them an inheritance among their brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this Job lived one hundred and forty years, and saw his children and grandchildren for four generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Job died, old and full of days.
speaker: Narrator
